Many people ask themselves when they play racing games, "How can racing games be both realistic and enjoyable simultaneously?". Several factors contribute to this. The most important component is the game mechanics. Racing games use a variety of gaming elements, such as track design, stages, challenges, drifting, customization, physics simulation, racing modes, and vehicle control—including acceleration, steering, and braking control. You can now see how the features and mechanics of racing games have changed throughout time. Let's now examine in more depth the key elements of racing games that are included in many well-known racing games. 1. Vehicle Control 2. Physics 3. Track Design 4. Power-Ups 5. Drifting 6. Nitro Boost 7. Customization 8. Vehicle Upgrades 9. Career Mode 10. Ghost Cars In addition, physics simulation, drift, vehicle control, powerups, stage design, obstacles, and racing modes are some of the typical game elements found in racing games. For the players to have smooth gaming, all of these mechanisms must cooperate. Get in contact with InvoGames if you intend to create your racing video games. a party for motor lovers | The USA Print What would an automotive festival in Hawaii be like? The Crew Motorfest aims to answer this question. The new thing from Ubisoft – which arrives today on PlayStation, Xbox and PC – is a mix between an arcade driving game and the large open worlds to which the French company has already accustomed us. Hundreds of cars to choose from to explore the main island of the Hawaiian archipelago: O’ahu. As in the Force Horizon – saga in which it has always been inspired The Crew – one of the main attractions of the game is driving freely through the open world. And go from the ash slope of a volcano, to the paradisiacal beaches of O’ahu, to the humid and lush jungle or to the streets of crowded Honolulu. All this choosing from more than 600 vehicles with options dating back to the 1950s. Read also Marc Brugat Content The Crew Motorfest is organized in playlists. There are 15 available at launch, but Ubisoft plans to release more throughout Season 1. Each playlist It is a small themed campaign and upon completion the player is rewarded with a unique vehicle. When entering one of these specific matches, not only do the vehicles change, but the island of O’ahu is adapted and decked out for the occasion. In the Made in Japan playlistFor example, Honolulu is filled with neon and in the Lamborghini campaign the island adopts a more Italian aesthetic. But the most interesting game mode is Vintage Garagewhich invites players to explore the evolution of cars between the 50s and the 90s. In this playlist, the gameplay adapts to the technology of the time so be prepared to drive without ABS or power steering. In addition, GPS did not exist, so orientation in races is based on photographs and maps. Image from ‘The Crew Motorfest’ Ubisoft As the name of the game already indicates – Motorfest – the new thing from Ubisoft is an automotive festival. Those looking for a simulator here would be better off waiting for the next one Forza Motorsportso that in The Crew You will not find realism of any kind (except in the graphic section). In this sense – and continuing with the comparison with the Microsoft franchise – The Crew Motorfest looks very similar to the Force Horizon. Beyond the playlist, Ubisoft also proposes several online game modes. These range from 28-player races to a mode Demolition with eight teams and a total of 32 players. In fact, everything that can be done in The Crew Motorfest It can be done cooperatively or competitively with friends on-line. Image from ‘The Crew Motorfest’ Ubisoft Another of the assets of this new The Crew It is collecting. In total there are more than 600 different fully customizable vehicles and a beauty and style contest is held weekly to evaluate the best designs.
